Award.AwardTitle: A National Network of Sonia Kovalevsky Mathematics Days
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the organization of 15 Sonia Kovalevsky Mathematics Days (named after the first woman ever to receive a Ph.D. degree in Mathematics) during March 2010 - March 2011. Each such activity is a day long program of engaging mathematics workshops specially designed to (1) attract middle school and high school girls to the study of mathematics and to support their interest in this discipline; (2) give the middle school and high school girl participants the chance to interact with college level women pursuing STEM degrees, women faculty in STEM disciplines, and professional women from industry or the financial sector; and (3) assist teachers with new ideas for teaching mathematics to girls and underrepresented minorities. The program activities will emphasize problem solving in interactive discovery activities involving discussions with experts, games, team projects, and mini-competitions.

The estimated number of participants served by this project is 1200 middle school and high school girls and 150 mathematics teachers. The proposed program is about exposure and opportunity, and it epitomizes the principle that equal opportunity to study mathematics yields similar performances of girls and boys .

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant was in support of (1) a national series of mathematical outreach activities (called Sonia Kovalevsky in honor of the first woman to ever receive a PhD degree in mathematics) sponsored on a competitive basis through the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) and (2) the presence of AWM at the first USA Science and Engineering Festival held in Washington DC in 2010.

The overarching goals of all activities supported through this grant were to support the interest of middle school and high school girls interested in mathematics, to attract junior women to the study of this field, and to create a support and mentoring network for these students, at the national level, consisting of professional women mathematicians working in  academia and industry, and women undergraduate and graduate students in mathematics.

Asa result, the Association for Women in Mathematics has supported through this grant the organization of 23 such mathematical outreach events hosted by a 22 different institutions of higher education in the United States. The activities were attended by over 3,000 middle school and high school students (out of which over 425 were coming from under-represented groups), and about 210 mathematics teachers (about 20 of them coming from minority groups). These mathematical outreach activities have been run by professional women mathematicians with the help of over 250 assistants.
